text: hey everyone thomas joseph here and few
things in life are better than a
perfectly roast chicken but does this
happen to you where your dark made those
legs and thighs they're undercooked but
your breast meat is overcooked
well today i'm going to show you the
best method for roasting chicken and the
secret is in spatchcocking a chicken so
in front of me here I have a whole
chicken and this is about a four pound
bird and now to spatchcock a chicken
it's very easy but if you're intimidated
you can ask your butcher to do this what
you're going to do is flip your bird
over breast side down and taking some
kitchen shears here cut out the backbone
of the chicken and this will enable us
to flatten the chicken if you are having
some trouble cutting through this
backbone that means that you're too far
over towards the leg or the wings so try
and stay in the center of the bird and
if you have a little bit of trouble come
in a little bit closer and it should be
very easy for you so this takes no time
at all
some people use serrated knives but I
find that kitchen shears work very well
and now the backbone saved this for
stock it's really great to keep it in
the freezer in a ziplock bag it will
last for a very long time and when you
have a bunch of them you can make a
delicious chicken stock now to flatten
the bird out flip it again breast side
towards me take the legs make sure that
they're pointing out and what you want
to do is to break the breastbone so
using your palms give the backbone a
push down and you should be able to hear
it which I just did flattening the bird
out like this helps the bird to cook
evenly so the dark meat which has to go
to 165 degrees is now on the outside or
the perimeter which has more heat right
the perimeter has more heat and the
breast meat is protected in the center
and only needs to cook to 150 degrees so
this configuration will ensure a evenly
cooked bird so I'm just going to move
this over to the side here cut up a
lemon into a pinch slices so now
position my lemons right in the center
of the rack here and this is
really for added flavor and of course as
always whenever I'm roasting I use a
wire rack and what this does is that
lifts up the protein off the bottom of
the pan and promotes even air
circulation around so now season up with
a little bit of olive oil here about a
tablespoon over the top this will ensure
that this skin gets nice and crisp
whenever you're roasting something like
a chicken or any big piece of meat you
really want to make sure that it's not
icy cold right out of the refrigerator
you want to make sure that the meat
comes to room temperature or close to it
so pull your chicken out about 40
minutes before you're ready to roast it
and this will help the chicken cook at a
more even rate so coarse kosher salt and
freshly ground black pepper you could
certainly use any other spice blend here
and now make sure your oven is preheated
to 425 degrees with the rack in the
middle of the oven and the chicken is
going in right now so the chicken has
been in the oven for about 20 minutes
and now add some shallots just to go
alongside so I have six shallots that
I've quartered here about a teaspoon of
olive oil salt and pepper
and scatter these around the chicken on
the wire rack and the chicken will
continue to cook for about twenty five
more minutes
you want to invest in a digital
thermometer it's the only way to tell
whether or not your chicken is cooked
correctly so insert your digital
thermometer into the thickest part of
the thigh and it should register 165
degrees Fahrenheit that's when you know
that your bird will be perfectly cooked
all right so the shallots into the oven
so the spatchcock chicken has been out
of the oven for about five to ten
minutes you don't want to cut it
immediately otherwise all those
wonderful juices are just going to drip
out now transfer this beautiful bird to
your cutting board here and actually
spatchcocking a chicken makes it really
easy to cut up into pieces take off the
thighs and the legs it's a piece of cake
to just separate them from the bird just
like that you can hear how crispy that
skin is and now simply to separate the
breasts all I'm going to do is cut it
right down the middle
this skin is so crisp that's what
everybody wants they want that crunchy
crisp skin take your chef's knife and
just cut the breast into to serve this
up with those wonderful roasted shallots
and I promise you guys this is going to
be your new favorite roast chicken
recipe give it a try and let us know
what you think write in the comment
section below and as always if you have
any kitchen conundrums let me know and I
will solve whatever problems you throw
my way enjoy
you
